TITLE.P: “Reduction of CO2 emissions by restoring degraded peatlands in Northern European Lowland”

SHORT_DESCR.P: The main objective of LIFE Peat Restore is the reduction of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions by restoration of degraded peatlands in Estonia, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland. In order to assess the climate effect of the restoration, (1.) the quantification of the baseline GHG dynamic of the project sites by using the GEST approach and (2.) the calculation of the GHG-emissions during the restoration measures also monitored by the GEST approach.

To obtain actual values of GHG emissions of the project sites and to calibrate the GEST results, additional annual direct GHG measurements of the three main GHG, CO2, CH4 and N2O are necessary. It will be expected, that the tenderers work in close collaboration with the Estonian working group during the contract period. Contact information will be provided to the awarded tenderer.

TITLE.P: Direct Greenhouse Gas Measurements in Biesenthaler Becken, Germany

SHORT_DESCR.P: Description of the procurement:

The procurement aims to obtain actual values of GHG emissions during the restoration measures and to calibrate values in the GEST-approach within the LIFE Peat Restore project in Germany. The tenderers are requested to plan works in the following steps:
1. preparation and/or construction of chamber, and application of existing chambers if suitable for project achievements;
2. development of a methodological approach to measure emissions of CO2 (Soil respiration and Netto Ecosystem Exchange), CH4 and N2O gases;
3. conduct annual measurement of all three main GHG from 1.4.2018 to 31.10.2020, 3 years during vegetation period, 8 times (measurements) per year;
4. submission of an annual report of GHG emissions data;
5. delivery of collected data quarterly.
Location of GHG emissions measurements:
Size: 15,5 hectares.
Conservation status: Nature Reserve, Natura 2000.
Habitat types: (Birch-) Bog forest (91D0*).
Climate: Temperate zone.
Temperatures: Ø January: -1 ºC, Ø July: 18 ºC.
Precipitation: Ø 789 mm/year.
Special consideration for measurements in Protected Areas.
Tenderers must be aware of possible special requirements due to the conservation status of the measurement site as a Nature Reserve and Natura 2000 site.
Time scale of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be conducted from 1.4.2018 until 31.10.2020. The measurements should be organised on a regular basis and interval between measurements have to be equal for all sites.
Basic Requirements in order to obtain reliable results:
— measurements should be done with collars / frames and at least with 3 spatial repetitions per measurement point,
— application of a suitable chamber size,
— application of fans, temperature sensors and a cooling system inside the chambers,
— in case of discrete manual gas sampling and subsequent analysis in the laboratory at least 4 single samples and a suitable closure time are required,
— measurements at least for CO2 have to be performed for each day of measurement under different radiation and temperature conditions,
— additional variables like temperature inside the chamber, peat temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation in the field at hourly base are also required for modelling.
Accuracy of GHG measurements.

The GHG emissions must be calculated using direct measurement values on site. In case of in situ measurements the measurement range should be from < 20 to 20 000 ppm for CO2, from < 20 to 200 ppm for CH4 and from < 20 to 1 000 ppb for N2O.
Data collection of GHG emissions measurements:
Each month data have to be duplicated in an external data base.
Reports of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be reported once a year until November 15 of each year and must include the following information:
1. monitoring site description and GHG measurement scheme;
2. climate conditions (air temperature, soil temperature, chamber temperature, air pressure, soil moisture, groundwater level, clouds, etc.);

3. all GHG emissions together with additional data of chamber temperature, soil temperature in 5 cm depth, photosynthetic active radiation. They must be reported additionally as an excel or text file to the Contracting Authority.
Deliverables:
The following deliverables are expected:
1. monitoring plan with site description and preliminary measurement dates;
2. an annual report of GHG emissions and quarterly provision of data;
3. a final report detailing all the activities performed under the contract.

TITLE.P: Direct Greenhouse Gas Measurements in Slowinski National Park, Poland

SHORT_DESCR.P: Description of the procurement:

This order aims to obtain and to estimate actual values of GHG emissions before and during the restoration measures and to calibrate values in the GEST-approach within the LIFE Peat Restore project in Germany. The tenderers are requested to plan works in the following steps:
1. preparation and/or construction of chamber, and application of existing chambers if suitable for project achievements;
2. development of a methodological approach to measure emissions of CO2 (Soil respiration and Netto Ecosystem Exchange), CH4 and N2O;
3. conduct annual measurement of all three main GHG (CO2, CH4, N2O) from 1.4.2018 to 31.10.2020, 3 years during vegetation period, 8 times (measurements) per year;
4. submission of an annual report of GHG emissions data;
5. delivery of collected data quarterly.
Location of GHG emissions measurements.
Size: 1350 hectares.
Conservation status: Natura 2000 (LRT and SPA), Unesco MAB Biosphere Reserve, Ramsar Site, International Bird Area (IBA).
Habitat types: Bog Forests (91D0*), Active raised bogs (7110*), Degraded raised bogs (which may still be capable of natural regeneration, 7120).
Climate: Temperate zone.
Temperatures: Ø January: -2,8 ºC, Ø July: 19 ºC.
Precipitation: Ø 652 mm/year.
Special consideration for measurements in Protected Areas:
Tenderers must be aware of possible special requirements due to the conservation status of the measurement site as a Nature Reserve and NATURA 2000 site.
Time scale of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be done from 1.4.2018 until 31.10.2020. The measurements should be organised on a regular basis and interval between measurements have to be equal for all sites:
Basic Requirements in order to obtain reliable results:
— measurements have to be done with collars / frames and at least with 3 spatial repetitions per measurement point,
— application of a suitable chamber size,
— application of fans, temperature sensors and a cooling system inside the chambers,
— in case of manual gas sampling and subsequent analysis in the laboratory at least 4 valid single samples and a suitable closure time are required,
— CO2-Measurements have to be performed repeatedly for each measurement day and plot under different radiation and temperature conditions,
— additional parameters like temperature inside the chamber, soil temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation in the field in hourly resolution are also required for modelling.
Accuracy of GHG measurements:

The GHG emissions must be calculated using direct measurement values on site. In case of in situ measurements the measurement range should be from < 20 to 20 000 ppm for CO2, from < 20 to 200 ppm for CH4 and from < 20 to 1 000 ppb for N2O.
Data collection GHG emissions measurements:
Each month data have to be saved in an external hard drive or another storage media.
Reports of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be reported once a year until November 15 of each year and must include the following information:
1. monitoring site description and GHG measurement scheme;
2. information about the climate conditions (air temperature, soil temperature, chamber temperature, air pressure, soil moisture, groundwater level, clouds, etc.);

3. information of all GHG emissions together with additional data of chamber temperature, soil temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation. The data must be provided additionally as an excel or text file to the Contracting Authority.
Deliverables:
The following deliverables are expected:
1. an annual report of GHG emissions and quarterly provision of data;
2. a final report detailing all the activities performed under the contract

TITLE.P: Direct Greenhouse Gas Measurements in Augstroze Nature Reserve, Lake Engure Nature Park and Baltezers Mire Nature Reserve, Latvia

MAIN_SITE.P: Engure Nature Park and Augstroze Nature Reserve — LV007.

SHORT_DESCR.P: Description of the procurement:

This order aims to obtain and to estimate actual values of GHG emissions before and during the restoration measures and to calibrate values in the GEST-approach within the LIFE Peat Restore project in Germany. The tenderers are requested to plan works in the following steps:
1. preparation and/or construction of chamber, and application of existing chambers if suitable for project achievements;
2. development of a methodological approach to measure emissions of CO2 (Soil respiration and Netto Ecosystem Exchange), CH4 and N2O;
3. conduct annual measurement of all three main GHG (CO2, CH4, N2O) from 1.4.2018 to 31.10.2020, 3 years during vegetation period, 8 times (measurements) per year;
4. submission of an annual report of GHG emissions data;
5. delivery of collected data quarterly.
Location of GHG emissions measurements:
Latvia, Augstroze Nature Reserve: 25.041605 ºE; 57.5802395 ºN.
Latvia, Lake Engure Nature Park: 23.135147 ºE; 57.2760746 ºN.
Latvia, Baltezers Mire Nature Reserve: 22.61931 ºE; 56.6770197 ºN.
Size: 248 hectares.
Conservation status: NATURA 2000, Nature Park, Internationally Important Bird Area, Ramsar Site.

Habitat types: Calcareous fens (7230), Calcareous fens with Cladium mariscus and species of the Caricion davallianae (7210*), Transition mires and quaking bogs (7140), Active raised bogs (7110*), Degraded raised bogs still capable of natural regeneration (7120), Depressions on peat substrates of the Rhynchosporion (7150).
Climate: Cool temperate zone.
Temperatures: Ø January: -2 ºC, Ø July: 18 ºC.
Precipitation: Ø 500-800 mm/year.
Special consideration for measurements in Protected Areas.
Tenderers must be aware of possible special requirements due to the conservation status of the measurement site as a Nature Reserve and Natura 2000 site.
Time scale of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be done from 1.4.2018 until 31.10.2020. The measurements should be organised on a regular basis and interval between measurements have to be equal for all sites.
Basic Requirements in order to obtain reliable results:
— measurements have to be done with collars / frames and at least with 3 spatial repetitions per measurement point,
— application of a suitable chamber size,
— application of fans, temperature sensors and a cooling system inside the chambers,
— in case of manual gas sampling and subsequent analysis in the laboratory at least 4 valid single samples and a suitable closure time are required,
— CO2-Measurements have to be performed repeatedly for each measurement day and plot under different radiation and temperature conditions,
— additional parameters like temperature inside the chamber, soil temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation in the field in hourly resolution are also required for modelling.
Accuracy of GHG measurements:

The GHG emissions must be calculated using direct measurement values on site. In case of in situ measurements the measurement range should be from < 20 to 20 000 ppm for CO2, from < 20 to 200 ppm for CH4 and from < 20 to 1 000 ppb for N2O.
Data collection GHG emissions measurements:
Each month data have to be saved in an external hard drive or another storage media.
Reports of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be reported once a year until November 15 of each year and must include the following information:
1. monitoring site description and GHG measurement scheme;
2. information about the climate conditions (air temperature, soil temperature, chamber temperature, air pressure, soil moisture, groundwater level, clouds, etc.);

3. information of all GHG emissions together with additional data of chamber temperature, soil temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation. The data must be provided additionally as an excel or text file to the Contracting Authority.
Deliverables:
The following deliverables are expected:
1. an annual report of GHG emissions and quarterly provision

TITLE.P: Direct Greenhouse Gas Measurements in Aukštumala, Sachara Peatland, Puščia and Amalvas Peatland, Lithuania

SHORT_DESCR.P: This order aims to obtain and to estimate actual values of GHG emissions before and during the restoration measures and to calibrate values in the GEST-approach within the LIFE Peat Restore project in Germany. The tenderers are requested to plan works in the following steps:
1. preparation and/or construction of chamber, and application of existing chambers if suitable for project achievements;
2. development of a methodological approach to measure emissions of CO2 (Soil respiration and Netto Ecosystem Exchange), CH4 and N2O;
3. conduct annual measurement of all three main GHG (CO2, CH4, N2O) from 1.4.2018 to 31.10.2020, 3 years during vegetation period, 8 times (measurements) per year;
4. submission of an annual report of GHG emissions data;
5. delivery of collected data quarterly.
Location of GHG emissions measurements:
Lithuania, Aukštumala: 21.430771 ºE; 55.391807 ºN.
Lithuania, Sachara Peatland: 25.48658 ºE; 55.94136 ºN.
Lithuania, Puščia: 26.09865 ºE; 55.67990 ºN.
Lithuania, Amalvas Peatland: 23.549837 ºE; 54.493313 ºN.
Size: 396 hectares.
Conservation status: Natura 2000: SPA, Landscape Reserve, Telmological Reserve, Ramsar Site, Regional Park.

Habitat types: Degraded raised bogs (which may still be capable of natural regeneration) (7120), Bog Forests (91D0*), Transitional and quaking bogs (7140), Active Raised Bogs (7110*), Depressions on peat substrates of the Rhynchosporion (7150).
Climate: Cool temperate continental climate.
Temperatures: Ø January: -6 ºC, Ø July: 17 ºC (Vilnius).
Precipitation: Ø 683 mm/year (Vilnius).
Special consideration for measurements in Protected Areas.
Tenderers must be aware of possible special requirements due to the conservation status of the measurement site as a Nature Reserve and Natura 2000 site.
Time scale of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be done from 1.4.2018 until 31.10.2020. The measurements should be organised on a regular basis and interval between measurements have to be equal for all sites.
Basic Requirements in order to obtain reliable results:
— measurements have to be done with collars / frames and at least with 3 spatial repetitions per measurement point,
— application of a suitable chamber size,
— application of fans, temperature sensors and a cooling system inside the chambers,
— in case of manual gas sampling and subsequent analysis in the laboratory at least 4 valid single samples and a suitable closure time are required,
— CO2-Measurements have to be performed repeatedly for each measurement day and plot under different radiation and temperature conditions,
— additional parameters like temperature inside the chamber, soil temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation in the field in hourly resolution are also required for modelling.
Accuracy of GHG measurements:

The GHG emissions must be calculated using direct measurement values on site. In case of in situ measurements the measurement range should be from < 20 to 20 000 ppm for CO2, from < 20 to 200 ppm for CH4 and from < 20 to 1 000 ppb for N2O.
Data collection GHG emissions measurements:
Each month data have to be saved in an external hard drive or another storage media.
Reports of GHG flux measurements:
The GHG flux measurements must be reported once a year until November 15 of each year and must include the following information:
1. monitoring site description and GHG measurement scheme;
2. information about the climate conditions (air temperature, soil temperature, chamber temperature, air pressure, soil moisture, groundwater level, clouds, etc.);

3. information of all GHG emissions together with additional data of chamber temperature, soil temperature in 5 cm depth and photosynthetic active radiation. The data must be provided additionally as an excel or text file to the Contracting Authority.
Deliverables:
The following deliverables are expected:
1. annual report of GHG emissions and quarterly provision of data;
2. final report detailing all the activities performed under the contract.
This part includes all activities of data analysis:
— flux calculation and statistical analysis,
— elaboration of suitable GHG-Exchange models,
— modelling annual GHG-Exchange.
Basic Requirements in order to obtain reliable results:
— greenhouse gas flux rates should be calculated based on at least a linear regression, other approaches can also be used, but must be present in detail in the implementation concept,
— GHG flux calculation should be performed according to the ideal gas law, other approaches can also be used, but must be present in detail in the implementation concept,
— flux rates must be given in mg CH4, CO2, N2O per m2 and hour and also in g CH4, CO2, N2O per m2 and day for every measurement day and presented in a suitable form,
— statistical data must be included, at least minimal, maximal values, means and standard deviation and presented in a suitable form,

— for Estimation and Modelling of annual fluxes the application of common approaches will be expected, at least the determination of temperature — response functions (Reco) and light-response function (GPP) for every day of measurement are essential for further calculations,
— results of modelled annual fluxes have to be given in t CH4, CO2, N2O per ha and year for every measurement period and presented in a suitable form,

— all tenderers are invited to make suggestions for a suitable model to estimate annual fluxes in the different Partner Countries, that integrate different on site recorded parameters and also allow for temporal and spatial extrapolation, a detailed description has to be included in the implementation concept,
— a close cooperation with the Estonian Partner team focused on the activities in this lot will be expected.
Accuracy of GHG measurements.

For GHG flux analysis it is important to use only low-noise fluxes, so at least a R2 of the regressions must be above 0,90 for CO2; 0,80 for CH4 and 0,80 for N2O. The Application of other more robust quality parameters are also welcome. For Modelling results we expect also the presentation of model goodness at least the denotation of the p-value together with the significance level. The Application of other more robust quality parameters are also welcome.
Data collection of GHG emissions measurements:
Each month data have to be saved in an external hard drive or another storage media.
Reports of GHG flux rate calculation and modelling:
The GHG flux rates and modelling results must be reported once a year until April 15th of each year and include the following information:
1. a detailed description of the used methodical approach for flux calculation and modelling;

2. suitable presentations of daily and annual fluxes of all different project sites, divided into specific Greenhouse Gases as a temporal progress and for CO2 we expect data presentation of the 3 separated fluxes (Reco, GPP and also the Net Ecosystem Exchange (NEE) as a result of the difference of GPP-Reco);
3. annexed to the report we expect a detailed overview of all flux data divided to the different sites, measurement days, Greenhouse Gases and information to the quality of the calculated data.
Deliverables:
The following deliverables are expected:
1. an annual report of GHG flux data and modelled annual emission data from all project sites;
2. a final report detailing all the activities performed under the contract

ACCELERATED_PROC.P: Seasonal constraints, contracted activities must start before spring of 2018.
